title: Chì mi na mòrbheanna
text:
Chì mi na mòrbheanna is a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> song that was written in 1856 by Highlander John Cameron (Iain Camshroin), a native of <a href="Ballachulish">Ballachulish</a> and known locally in the Gaelic fashion as Iain Rob and Iain Òg Ruaidh. He worked in the slate quarries before moving to Glasgow where he was engaged as a ship's broker. He became the Bard of the Glasgow Ossianic Society and also Bard to Clan Cameron. He returned to carry on a merchant's business along with his elder brother and to cultivate a small croft at Taigh a' Phuirt, <a href="Glencoe%2C%20Highland">Glencoe</a>, in his beloved Highlands. Other songs and odes appeared in <a href="The%20Oban%20Times">The Oban Times</a> and in various song books. He was buried in St. Munda's Isle in Loch Leven. Wreaths of oak leaves and ivy covered the bier
The song is a longing for home and, with its wistful, calming melody and traditional ballad rhythms, is often used as a lullaby. A Gaelic arrangement of the song was recorded on Cape Breton, Nova Scotia folk singer <a href="John%20Allan%20Cameron">John Allan Cameron</a>'s 1973 album "Lord Of The Dance", and <a href="The%20Rankin%20Family">The Rankin Family</a>'s debut album (1989). The song was also played during the funerals of <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> and <a href="Joe%20Strummer">Joe Strummer</a>.
This song is commonly known in English as "The Mist-Covered Mountains of Home," and under that title it has been recorded by many artists, including <a href="John%20Renbourn">John Renbourn</a>, <a href="Mark%20Knopfler">Mark Knopfler</a>, <a href="Johnny%20Cunningham">Johnny Cunningham</a>, <a href="Nightnoise">Nightnoise</a> (at the time "including" Johnny Cunningham) and <a href="Quadriga%20Consort">Quadriga Consort</a>.
